clinical_summary: Serial laboratory evaluations from March to June 2025 show a persistently normal complete blood count with hemoglobin 135 g/dL, RBC 5.05 million/µL, WBC 7500‑8200/µL and a normal peripheral smear; liver enzymes (ALT 10‑10 U/L, AST 12‑12 U/L) and alkaline phosphatase (70 U/L) remained within reference ranges, while total bilirubin was elevated at 4.1 mg/dL on 2025‑03‑26 and decreased to 1.4 mg/dL on 2025‑06‑28 (direct bilirubin 0.6 mg/dL on both dates); C‑reactive protein was modestly elevated (4.2 mg/dL then 1.8 mg/dL) and procalcitonin remained low (0.10‑0.13 ng/mL), with a documented sepsis risk score of 6.5 on the latest report despite normal white cell differential; renal function (BUN 24 mg/dL, creatinine 0.4 mg/dL) and electrolytes (Na 137 mmol/L, K 4.2 mmol/L, Cl 96 mmol/L) were unremarkable.

differential_diagnoses.name: Gilbert syndrome
differential_diagnoses.justification: Mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia (total bilirubin up to 4.1 mg/dL, indirect bilirubin at upper normal limit) with normal liver enzymes and no anemia.

differential_diagnoses.name: Early hepatic dysfunction or cholestasis
differential_diagnoses.justification: Elevated total bilirubin persisting across visits despite normal ALT/AST, suggesting possible early liver or biliary impairment.

differential_diagnoses.name: Sepsis (low probability)
differential_diagnoses.justification: Documented sepsis risk score of 6.5 but low procalcitonin, modest CRP, and normal white cell count make active sepsis unlikely.

differential_diagnoses.name: Hemolysis (unlikely)
differential_diagnoses.justification: Slightly elevated indirect bilirubin without accompanying anemia or abnormal reticulocyte data.
